statement.text: Prosthetic rehabilitation after amputation follows Medicare functional classification (K-levels) that predict ambulatory potential and guide prosthetic prescription, with K-level 2-3 typically required for functional community ambulation.

explanation.intuition: Not every amputee can or wants to walk with a prosthesis. K-levels classify patients by their potential - from K0 (won't walk) to K4 (can run). This helps match the right prosthetic technology to the patient's abilities and goals.
explanation.key_insight: The K-level determines prosthetic prescription and coverage. K2 (limited community ambulator) is typically minimum for microprocessor knees. Pre-amputation mobility, cognition, and comorbidities predict post-amputation K-level.
explanation.technical_details: K-levels: K0 (non-ambulatory/household only without prosthesis), K1 (household ambulator), K2 (limited community - uneven terrain), K3 (community ambulator - varied speeds), K4 (exceeds basic ambulation - athletics). Factors predicting success: pre-amputation mobility, BKA vs AKA (BKA 70% ambulatory, AKA 30%), age, comorbidities, motivation. Prosthetic progression: immediate post-op (rigid dressing), preparatory prosthesis (6-8 weeks), definitive prosthesis (3-6 months).

k_levels.K0: Does not have ability or potential to ambulate or transfer
k_levels.K1: Household ambulator - can walk on level surfaces
k_levels.K2: Limited community ambulator - can traverse low-level obstacles
k_levels.K3: Community ambulator - varied cadence, most environmental barriers
k_levels.K4: Exceeds basic ambulation - high impact, athletic

clinical_pearls: Pre-amputation mobility is strongest predictor of post-amputation ambulation
BKA has 2x higher prosthetic ambulation rate than AKA (70% vs 30%)
K2+ level typically required for microprocessor knee coverage
